Headline.Para: The 10-Point.A personal, guided tour to the best scoops and stories every day in The Wall Street Journal, from Editor in Chief Gerard Baker.

TailParas.Para: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un met Chinese President Xi Jinping this week during a surprise trip to Chinaâ€”a visit some contend is an attempt to mend fences with Beijing ahead of a planned summit with President Trump. It was believed to be his first foreign trip and first meeting with another world leader since taking power in 2011. Mr. Kim met Mr. Xi and other senior officials to discuss bilateral ties and tensions on the Korean Peninsula, Chinese state media said. Mr. Kim told Mr. Xi that Pyongyang is committed to denuclearizing the Korean Peninsula and is willing to start dialogue with the U.S. and hold a summit, a Chinese government-run news agency said. The White House said it saw Mr. Kim's visit to China as further evidence that its "campaign of maximum pressure is creating the appropriate atmosphere for dialogue with North Korea." China had briefed the White House about the North Korean leader's trip, it said. Rumors that Mr. Kim might be visiting Beijing circulated through diplomatic circles after Japanese media reported Monday that a high-ranking North Korean official may have arrived in the Chinese capital on a special train.

Technology stocks are suffering one of their worst beatings in years, as investors reassess a sector that has driven global growth but now faces the prospect of greater regulatory scrutiny. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index fell 2.9% Tuesday, as mounting troubles at Facebook and others cloud the industry's outlook. Stocks in Asia and Europe fell Wednesday as tech shares continued to slide, and futures pointed to an opening loss of 0.4% for the S&P 500. Facebook Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg is planning to testify before Congress about the company's privacy and data-use standards, according to people familiar with the matter. The Federal Trade Commission has signaled it is conducting a broad probe of the social-media giant, while 37 state attorneys general are also demanding explanations for its practices. Meanwhile, companies are paying the most in nearly a decade for some types of short-term borrowing. The three-month Libor rose to 2.29%, its highest level since November 2008. The benchmark used to set interest rates on trillions of dollars in loans climbed nearly a full percentage point in the past six months, outpacing the Federal Reserve's rate increases. But investors shouldn't be too pessimistic, writes the Journal's Nathaniel Taplin. A trade war between the U.S. and China might be a commodities-buying opportunity, thanks to Beijing's likely response: another round of stimulus measures that would push metals demand higher again.

The decision by the Trump administration to ask 2020 census respondents whether they are U.S. citizens was met with swift and strong opposition, setting the stage for multiple battles over the decennial population count. New York's attorney general said he would lead a multistate lawsuit to stop the administration from adding the question to the census, after he and 18 other attorneys general and one governor wrote last month to Commerce Department Secretary Wilbur Ross, who oversees the Census Bureau, urging him not to proceed with the plan. Civil-rights groups and minority advocates said the question would dissuade immigrants, particularly noncitizens, from answering the census altogether, resulting in undercounts. The census aims to count every resident regardless of legal status. The federal government relies on the tallies to allocate congressional seats, craft poverty guidelines and distribute billions of dollars in funding for programs such as Medicaid. Beyond the politics, the move poses practical challenges because test forms for the 2020 count have already been sent without the new query.

There's a rising star in the crowded talk-show space that is getting celebrities to say anything through an unorthodox interview method: hot sauce. On "Hot Ones," a self-aware, situation talk show on YouTube, celebrity guests sit with host Sean Evans at a bare-bones set and talk about their careers while eating 10 progressively spicier chicken wings. Guests regularly freak out in the process, giving candid interviews to audiences in the millions. Sauces such as Da Bomb Beyond Insanity and Blair's Mega Death appear to have a physiological impact. Sniffles and tears burst loose. They try to douse the fire with milk, yogurt or rice. Their answers get more raw as the Scoville ratingâ€”a measure of hot-pepper hotnessâ€”rises to face-melting levels. Music builds the drama like a Hans Zimmer action-movie score. It's a talk show with its own story arc.
For Windows laptops, the pricing sweet spot is $1,000. The Journal's David Pierce walks you through the best options from Microsoft, Dell, HP, Lenovo and Acer, and lands on an overall great pick.

TailParas.Para: The number of Jaguar vehicles Waymo is buying for its driverless fleet. The deal is potentially worth more than $1 billion, and escalates Waymo's effort to put vehicles on public roads without human drivers behind the wheel.

Going back to our story above, do you think 2020 census should ask respondents if they are U.S. citizens? Send your comments, which we may edit before publication, to 10point@wsj.com. Please include your name and location.

Responding to yesterday's question on rising tensions between Russia and the West, Bill Higgins of Florida said: "Russia's invasion of Georgia and eastern Ukraine, intervention in Syria, the killing of a Russian Ã©migrÃ© a few years ago in England, and the attempted murder of an exchanged Russian spy and his daughter with a Soviet-developed nerve agent only weeks ago announce a Russian return to fierce adversary. Western response has been uneven and minimal. NATO members need to improve their militaries in a coordinated fashion. NATO should consider basing heavy brigades in eastern Germany and the Balkan countries. Let's deter Russia." James Hyland of Wisconsin wrote: "Diplomatic expulsions are not uncommon when Cold War-like mayhem takes place. There will now be the predictable counter play by Russia. All of this is to be expected. In the midst of all the Russophobia that envelops his administration, President Trump has shown he can walk a fine line when it comes to dealing with Putin." And Barbara Wickwire of Florida replied: "I am reminded of the movie 'The Russians Are Coming, the Russians Are Coming.' But now the Russians are going, the Russians are going."

This daily briefing is named "The 10-Point" after the nickname conferred by the editors of The Wall Street Journal on the lead column of the legendary "What's News" digest of top stories. Technically, "10-point" referred to the size of the typeface. The type is smaller now but the name lives on.
